LengthCluster.description: Check whether the prediction length fits most of the BLAST hit lengths, by 1D hierarchical clusterization. Meaning of the output displayed: Query_length [Main Cluster Length Interval]
LengthCluster.approach: If the query sequence is well conserved and similar sequences (BLAST hits) are correct, we can expect query and hit sequences to have similar lengths. Here, we cluster the lengths of hit sequences and compare the length of our query sequence to the most dense cluster of hit lengths.
LengthCluster.explanation: The most dense length-cluster of BLAST hits includes sequences that are from 124 to 137 amino-acids long. The query sequence is 132 amino-acids long and is thus inside the most dense length-cluster of BLAST hits.
LengthCluster.conclusion: There is no reason to believe there is any problem with the length of the query sequence.

graphs.title: Length Cluster Validation: Distribution of BLAST hit lengths
graphs.footer: Query Sequence, black;Most Dense Cluster,red;Other Hits, blue

LengthRank.description: Check whether the rank of the prediction length lies among 80% of all the BLAST hit lengths.
LengthRank.approach: If the query sequence is well conserved and similar sequences (BLAST hits) are correct, we can expect query and hit sequences to have similar lengths.
LengthRank.explanation: The query sequence is  132 amino-acids long. BLAST identified 7 hit sequences with lengths from 124 to 2192 amino-acids (median: 136; mean: 429). 3 of these hit sequences (i.e. 43%) are shorter than the query sequence.
LengthRank.conclusion: There is no reason to believe there is any problem with the length of the query sequence.

GeneMerge.description: Check whether BLAST hits make evidence about a merge of two genes that match the predicted gene.
GeneMerge.approach: We expect the query sequence to encode a single protein-coding gene. Here, we analyse the High-scoring Segment Pairs (HSPs) identified by BLAST to determine whether the query includes sequence from two or more genes.
GeneMerge.explanation: The start coordinates and the end coordinates of HSPs are unimodally distributed.
GeneMerge.conclusion: This suggest that the query sequence represents a single gene.

graphs.title: Gene Merge Validation: Start/end of matching hit coord. on query (1 point/hit)
Gene Merge Validation: Query coord covered by blast hit (1 line/hit)

Duplication.description: Check whether there is a duplicated subsequence in the predicted gene by counting the hsp residue coverage of the prediction, for each hit.
Duplication.approach: We expect each BLAST hit to match each region of the query at most once. Here, we calculate the distribution of hit coverage against the query sequence and use the Wilcoxon test to determine if it is higher than 1.
Duplication.explanation: The Wilcoxon test produced a p-value of 1.
Duplication.conclusion: This suggests that the query sequence contains no erroneous duplications.

MissingExtraSequences.description: Finds missing and extra sequences in the prediction, based on the multiple alignment of the best hits. Also counts the percentage of the conserved regions that appear in the prediction.
